content.title: Renal Biopsy
content.summary: Renal biopsy is the gold standard for diagnosing glomerular diseases, unexplained AKI, proteinuria, and transplant dysfunction. Performed percutaneously under ultrasound guidance, it provides tissue for light microscopy, immunofluorescence, and electron microscopy. Complications include bleeding (most common), but serious events are rare with proper patient selection.
key_points: Indications: unexplained AKI, glomerulonephritis, nephrotic syndrome, proteinuria >1g/day, transplant dysfunction
Contraindications: uncontrolled HTN, bleeding diathesis, solitary kidney (relative), uncooperative patient
Technique: ultrasound-guided percutaneous; lower pole of left kidney; 2-3 cores obtained
Processing: light microscopy (LM), immunofluorescence (IF), electron microscopy (EM)
Complications: gross hematuria (5-7%), perinephric hematoma, need for transfusion (<1%), nephrectomy (rare)
Post-procedure: bed rest 4-6 hours, serial vitals, Hgb monitoring
content.statement: Renal biopsy remains essential for diagnosing and guiding treatment of glomerular diseases. Proper patient selection and technique minimize complications, making it a safe and informative procedure.

explanation.intuition: Many kidney diseases have similar clinical presentations (proteinuria, hematuria, AKI) but different underlying pathology requiring different treatments. Biopsy reveals the histologic pattern, immune deposits, and ultrastructural changes that distinguish diagnoses and guide therapy.
explanation.key_insight: A complete renal biopsy requires all three microscopy modalities: LM for general structure, IF for immune deposits (IgG, IgA, IgM, C3, C4, C1q, kappa, lambda), and EM for basement membrane abnormalities and electron-dense deposits. Missing any modality limits diagnostic accuracy.
explanation.technical_details: Adequate sample: ≥10 glomeruli for native kidney, ≥7 for transplant. Pre-procedure: hold anticoagulation, check BP (goal <150/90), platelet count >50,000, INR <1.5, bleeding time. Use 16-18 gauge automated needle. Target lower pole to avoid major vessels.

definitions_glossary.renal_biopsy: Procedure obtaining kidney tissue for histologic diagnosis of renal diseases
definitions_glossary.percutaneous_biopsy: Kidney biopsy performed through skin under imaging guidance; standard approach
definitions_glossary.light_microscopy: Standard microscopy with H&E, PAS, trichrome, silver stains for general structure
definitions_glossary.immunofluorescence: IF: detects immune deposits (IgG, IgA, IgM, C3, C4, fibrin) using fluorescent antibodies
definitions_glossary.electron_microscopy: EM: ultrastructural analysis showing basement membrane and electron-dense deposits
definitions_glossary.glomerulonephritis: Inflammatory glomerular disease; often requires biopsy for diagnosis
definitions_glossary.adequate_sample: Sufficient tissue for diagnosis; typically ≥10 glomeruli for native kidney biopsy
definitions_glossary.perinephric_hematoma: Blood collection around kidney; most common significant complication
definitions_glossary.transplant_biopsy: Biopsy of transplanted kidney for rejection, BK nephropathy, or recurrent disease
definitions_glossary.banff_classification: Standardized histologic classification for transplant kidney biopsies
definitions_glossary.crescentic_gn: Rapidly progressive GN with cellular crescents; biopsy essential for diagnosis
definitions_glossary.arteriovenous_fistula: Rare biopsy complication from injury to adjacent vessels

pathophysiology.mechanism: The kidney contains multiple compartments (glomeruli, tubules, interstitium, vessels) that can be differentially affected by diseases. Biopsy allows direct visualization of pathology: glomerular scarring, immune complex deposition, tubular injury, interstitial fibrosis, vascular changes. Pattern recognition guides diagnosis and treatment.
pathophysiology.clinical_significance: Many glomerular diseases require immunosuppression with significant side effects. Biopsy confirms diagnosis before initiating therapy and helps predict prognosis based on chronicity indices.

native_kidney: Systemic disease with renal involvement (lupus, vasculitis)
Unexplained CKD when diagnosis would change management

pre_procedure.imaging: Ultrasound to assess kidney size, location, exclude contraindications

procedure.target: Lower pole of left kidney (or transplant in RLQ)

monitoring: Serial vital signs q15min × 4, then q30min × 4
post_procedure.discharge: Same-day if stable; no strenuous activity × 1 week

skos.definition: A diagnostic procedure obtaining kidney tissue for histologic analysis to diagnose glomerular, tubulointerstitial, and vascular kidney diseases

cpt.description: Renal biopsy, percutaneous, by trocar or needle

learning_objectives: Identify indications and contraindications for renal biopsy
Describe the three microscopy modalities used in renal biopsy analysis
Recognize common complications and their management
Interpret biopsy findings in the context of clinical presentation
clinical_pearls: Complete biopsy requires LM + IF + EM; missing any limits diagnosis
Adequate sample: ≥10 glomeruli native kidney, ≥7 transplant
Gross hematuria in 5-7% is usually self-limited
Post-biopsy AV fistula: continuous bruit over kidney + delayed HTN
Transplant biopsies are safer (superficial, no respiratory movement)
If creatinine rises post-biopsy, suspect large hematoma or clot obstruction
common_misconceptions: Light microscopy alone is sufficient (IF and EM often essential)
Solitary kidney is absolute contraindication (relative; can biopsy with caution)
All AKI needs biopsy (only when etiology unclear and would change management)
